reviewText: Some people may find history long and boring, but the writer/director and host of this series manages to make India's history come to life through his own enthusiasm and obvious love of the country. Having travelled in India by the seat of my pants, I can say that he captures it all as an adventurer would, never do you feel like you are being led in some tour group, but rather that you are exploring it together! He is more like a seasoned traveling partner full of knowledge and anecdote, traversing you through times ancient, down through the ages one by one to modern times, like layers of unearthed exploration.  He manages to do all this with nods to the gods, various religions, occupiers, conquerors, and peoples that shaped the history and fell in love with this very diverse, spiritually enchanting, and long enduring land and made it their home. Compelling and a definite must see, a history very important to understand, as India will shape much of our worlds future.

reviewText: Michael Wood goes mad in India.  The scope of his material is too vast, he is overwelmed and so are we, yet the monumentality is bewitching, we are caught up in it,want it never to end.  Why are there so few chapters?  India is the mother culture and has so many insights, inroads and quirks.  And so we are trapped, like Michael, under showers of colored powders and legends and kingdoms, of appalling cruelty and dazzling humanity. This is how the world is, larger than life and eternal.
summary: A World From the Beginning of Time

reviewText: On a technical level, this is perhaps the finest documentary I've ever seen.  The photography is just spectacular - I'm an amateur still photographer and I found myself often pausing the DVD to admire a brilliant composition.  The aerial maps and graphics are also superb.  I found the writing and narration by Wood so good.  His passion is contagious and his voice appealing.I'm not in a position to debate the historical accuracy of the documentary nor to weigh in on the extent of the bias.  Seems the intent was to deliver an overview of Indian history in an alluring and appealing package that is part documentary and part travelogue.  Perhaps not intended for the scholar or academic, but rather for the culturally- and historically-inclined among the masses.

Too bad the climate is so hot in India otherwise it would be an even more popular travel destination.This India makes it hard to believe the news stories about New Delhi assaults and the trade in Nepalese girls. reviewText: The other reviews here spell out beautifully just how beautiful this miniseries documentary really is. Michael Wood never fails to leave me mesmerised and spellbound, whether talking about Shakespeare (in his Shakespeare documentary, he noted in one contemporary list was spelt 'SHAXBARD') or underplaying the fact that the Khyber Pass is dangerous as hell (in this documentary).What I love best is that Michael Wood cannot be ignored as the consummate BRITISH writer/documentarist/host. His nearest counterpart, with just a bit of TV work under his belt, is British archaeologist Dr. John Romer. The British have a way with documentaries, a quiet, thorough and completely satisfying way of presenting, teaching, elucidating and the rare ability to have fun.Michael Wood is as I said the example. In this he sets the example better than ever. If you want to truly understand the history of India and its people, this is the only documentary to watch. The only negative comment I have about this series is the oft-mentioned scene dealing with the drink Soma. I loved every minute of it, but couldn't Michael have spent a lot more time on the Aryanas, or the Indus Valley culture? These things need documentaries all their own...but Michael sometimes gets carried away with the moment......and this leads to his hilarity that is so wonderful and professorial at its best. After sampling Soma, he voices over that "it...makes one talk too much!" At a festival in southern India, he roars into the camera over thousands of voices in the crowd that India is the only place in the world where one can be run over by Bronze Age priests. Hilarious and educational.No one does it like Michael. If you haven't watched much of Wood, get all the documentaries of his that you can. You may yawn a bit watching his Shakespeare documentary because of the ham actors doing extended scenes; you may not like the way he stops short of a proper, full perspective of certain subjects. I still cannot obtain his "Islands of Britain" (2009)--perhaps the best documentary ever made.But I'll be getting it when I can! And so should you!

reviewText: I obtained this film from Netflix and subsequently purchased it from Amazon.com. This film is completely objective in its history of India, from the distant past, to the horrors of English rule, and subsequent partitioning of Northern India into pieces of Pakistan. Michael Wood's narration and emotional explanations makes me appreciate India more than ever. My main interest in India is spiritual.  I was disappointed that there was no mention of Sri Ramakrishna, and his disciple Swami Vivekananda who did so much to help India. But, in appreciating Wood's excellent presentation, great filming and editing, and his capture of the people of India, I give it 5 stars.

reviewText: The Story of India is one told of an incredibly rich and complex civilization whose roots are found in humanity's earliest migrations out of Africa.  India has been the site of invasions by Aryans, perhaps from Turkmenistan, later Alexander the Great, of internal conquests and battles, and eventually from Moghuls and the British.  There have been golden ages, and enlightened rulers, such as Ashok the Great, who after engaging in countless battles, sought peace and compassion for all, promulgating his edicts.  It is a remarkably complex and rich culture and this serves as an overview and introduction.  The only fault I find in this series is that it is not entirely linear, it jumps about from place to place and a bit from time to time, making connections, but not always keeping things clear.  You might need to take notes or find other sources to keep things in order.
summary: Lovely BBC/PBS Presentation about the History of India

reviewText: Hosted by an acclaimed historian, The Story of India with Michael Wood is a six-part DVD tour (also available in Blu-Ray format) of the incredibly rich and complex history of India, a nation populated by a diverse confluence of peoples, cultures, and environments. From the deserts of Turkmenistan to the Khyber Pass, the plains of Pakistan, the majestic Himalayas, and much more, India is a vast land and with a storied historical narrative that spans millennia. "The Sights and Sounds of India" special feature enhances this lengthy and involving documentary, highly recommended for armchair travelers as well as public library collections. 6 hours, closed captioned.
summary: Highly recommended for armchair travelers as well as public library collections

reviewText: My review of the book that accompanied this BBC production was not effusive in praise. But when it comes to the DVD this product fares much better.Effectively what you are getting here is TV style historian chap Michael Wood cruises across the Indian subcontinent looking at the history of an incredibly resilient and vibrant culture and peoples. He starts at the beginning in terms of discussing what we know about the earliest migrations and then moves to discussing the Harappan civilisation. From there he moves closer and closer to the present day, criss-crossing many many miles to visit not just some of the marquee items such as the Taj Mahal but also many smaller temples and places of significance. One of the main themes of the work is of looking at the continuity of Indian culture and how holy places have remained in use for millennia in India in a way that is rarely, if ever, matched anywhere else in the world.One downfall of the series is that it fails do really define much of a chronological timeline. It moves from ancient times to modern in regular pattern but it seems lacking in definition, though it is in better shape in this regard than the book.The photography is lovely, the sense of the size and the population of India is brought across well and much time is spent on the diversity of the peoples and religions of India in a way that casts a very positive light. In fact there is much attention paid to the way that India has absorbed so much over the years and added it to its own mix and this is also shown in a very positive light.Despite being from the BBC the British are not spared a good drubbing in relation to their dealings with India. Of course going about creating an empire was the done thing so there is no faux hand wringing on that score so much but the conduct of the British during the partition is found particularly wanting.All up the six episodes of this show put on display the vibrant nature of India and the grandeur and importance of her history. It certainly does it in a colourful way.
Title: N/A

reviewText: You know why Michael Wood's programs are so compelling? Because you can tell he is in awe of the grandeur of history. Or as he puts it; 'the layers of history'. His fascination spews out in his speech, his facial expressions, the way he blends background music, the way he photographs. It all captivates the viewer. Of course it helps that he has a British accent which, to our ears, we equate with scholarship. Because somehow when a breathless Englishman says; 'The fall of the Roman Empire !!' or 'Palace intrigues and the murder of...' someone or other, it just somehow sounds more important. I have seen all his programs and this Story of India is certainly one of THE best.

reviewText: This documentary is one of the best out there on India. I disagree with other reviewers that a lot has been left out. If one tries to cover everything about India, one would have to shoot several episodes and can very well lose the interest of the viewers.This documentary is like the super-abridged version of the (hi)story of India. Many in India may not know the facts that are covered in the first few episodes. I liked the fact that there is a lot of coverage on South India. The way Michael Wood has shown that the historical boundaries of India stretch far beyond the current boundaries of India is interesting and educative.Perhaps he got carried away by the Soma drink. He could have spent much less time on the drink. But he makes up for it with his enthusiasm. He looks genuinely enthused about the story of India. The documentary shows India in a positive and different light than the other typical documentaries on India.One flaw (repeated at least a couple of times) is the map of Tamilnadu. Instead of superimposing the word 'Tamilnadu' over the state of Tamilnadu in the Indian map, it has been placed over Sri Lanka. This error is glaring. We expect better from the BBC and Michael Wood.Of course, one might always feel that a lot more could have been covered, but I feel that Mr. Wood has tried to strike a right balance in this short and crisp version of the Story of India.A must have for emigrant Indian families and school/ university libraries.

reviewText: To his credit, English historian and broadcaster Michael Wood does a great job of making several aspects of the Indian history accessible to a wide audience.  Although Wood mainly focuses on India, he also looks at the contribution of what are today's Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, to name a few countries, to the history of India.  Wood gives the 50,000-foot view of for example the Harappan civilization, the Buddha and Buddhism, the Chola Kingdom, the Mughal Empire, the British Raj, and India's struggle for freedom.  Wood spends much time on exploring the life of ordinary Indians.  What viewers glean from watching this series is that most Indians remain close to their cultural, religious roots while being open to change.  However, "The Story of India" DVD box set is ultimately a disappointment.  Whoever is looking for an in-depth documentary about the history of India and its interaction with the outside world will be disappointed.  Those viewers will gain more by reading "India a History" by John Keay, "After Tamerlane the Global History of Empire Since 1405" by John Darwin, and "A Splendid Exchange How Trade Shaped the World" by William Bernstein.
summary: India: Exhilarating Blend of Continuity and Change
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've always been fascinated with India. It's always been a land for fairytale and mystery for me and after watching "The Story of India" my fascination has only grown.  "Story of India" is a six hour long documentary hosted by English historian Michael Wood. (being American, I couldn't help but laugh when I heard him pronounce India "In-der-a") It's divided into six, hour long episodes each one covering a unique aspect of the country.Episode 1: "Beginnings" covers how the first Indians came out of Africa and began their civilizationEpisode 2: "The Power of Ideas" lean how India became a center for intellect and religion. The begins of Buddhism and the ideas of India's great leaders are discussed.Episode 3: "Spice Routes and Silk Roads" see how India became a powerful trade center exporting exotic spices to Rome and ChinaEpisode 4: "Ages of Gold" How the great king "Raja Raja" brought forth the Indian Renaissance and made great strides in humanitarianism.Episode 5: "The meeting of Two Oceans" A fascinating look at Islam's spread into India and its clash with Hinduism. See how leaders on both sides worked for peace and the relationship of the two beliefs today.Episode 6 "Freedom" India's struggle against Brittan and how the war was ultimately won, not though bloodshed but with peace.After watching "Story of India" I'm more in love with India than I've ever been and I'm certain I will visit it someday. A country of stunning beauty where the past coexists with the present, the importance of Indian history is paramount. If you have any interest in India at all then this documentary is an absolute must see.
summary: With India there is never only one side of a story

reviewText: I'm not an Indian historian, but rather a Russian historian; however, after watching this series, I asked an Indian historian about this documentary, and her comments supported my response: the earlier episodes are extremely problematic, but it gets better at the end.Basically, the first episode is a kind of mockumentary, as others have said.  There's a lot of simply inaccurate information in there.  I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.  The other early episodes also suffer from Wood's insistence that the past is still fully alive in present-day India.  While there is of course some truth to this, it also has an aspect of Orientalism, as the idea of timeless mother India was a big part of the justifications for British imperialism.  Also, the British did change a lot of things, so hoping to find evidence of how things were 1000 years ago today strikes me as highly problematic.I like how the series has information on South India, but I can't help but wonder if it really is the world's only surviving classical civilization.  Doesn't that seem to imply that there hasn't been change?I showed the last episode, "Freedom," to my upper-level undergraduate class on Imperialism.  It was very successful in generating lots of discussion.  There's so much to say about imperialism in the episode.  Wood feels it was India's destiny to be colonized by the British. In general there's a tension between the two aims of the episode: to argue that India is the world's largest democracy and Britain is the mother of democracies and then also to somehow come to terms with British colonization in some kind of real way.  It's not a whitewash of the British - he's especially and rightfully critical of the British and how they didn't protect anyone during Partition - but he doesn't let slip any opportunity to mention Brits who contributed to Indian culture. There was a lot of discussion about Partition in my class, as no one had heard of it before, as well as about the archives and documents shown.  That is a good point of the documentary - how it shows him in archives.  Also, watching him interact with Indians provided interesting material for a discussion of the aftereffects of imperialism in personal relationships.I personally was most impressed by the episode on the Mughals, titled "The Meeting of Two Oceans."  Wood uses the example of the Mughals to argue against the clash of civilizations thesis and focuses on Akbar to suggest that there was an opening to create a lasting Indo-Muslim culture.  I have taught the Mughals many times in World Civilizations and it was fascinating to see the places they built.  The discussion of the Taj Mahal as an expression of a Sufi view of paradise was very interesting.In general, be careful of the early episodes, but the last two are definitely worth using in a class.
summary: I'd show the last two episodes to a class, but not earlier ones

reviewText: An enjoyable overview of Indian history and culture.  I got this as part of my preliminary studies for a trip to the subcontinent, but it did not really prepare me for what I actually saw there firsthand.  It does give you a sense of the history of the region, and of the different cultures that make up modern India.  Michael Wood's effusive good cheer grows a bit tiresome over the course of six hours.  It is not great, but it is worth a look.
summary: Pretty good overview of the subject

reviewText: Wonderful video explaining and showing the history of India - starting from almost 1,000 years ago.  It includes migration, silk trade, written history on metal in Temples, archeology, religion, unbelievable metal work done, astrology, development of modern math...and so much more.  Seen on my Kindle  Fire HD - WOW.

reviewText: India has such an amazing and rich history. This documentary was really well done and showcased the history of India beginning with the migrations out of Africa.What a fascinating culture. I hope to visit India one day.I can't wait to watch the rest of the series.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This six episode documentary covers Indian prehistory and history from the early classical empires through the Mogul empire and British colonial empire.  This is all done by Michael Wood, the narrator, by traveling through contemporary Indian, Pakistan, and Afghanistan, telling the "story" with the land and people as the background.  It is amazing how he brings to life those ancient and more recent times by simply walking through the countryside and talking (in both English and Hindi) to people.  The documentary is as stunning, visually, as the the story of India itself.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Story of India is a intriguing overview study of this ancient culture. While it does not answer all the questions it raises, it does a very good job providing the viewer with a general introduction to one of the planet's oldest and most diverse cultures. While I might have liked to see greater time devoted to the British period, the series did an adequate job given the constraints of time the program had. There are other, more specific documentaries devoted to specific parts of the Indian history but for a start to present overview, this is excellent.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This may be one of the best documentaries ever made.  Michael Wood takes us on a tour of all of the regions, history, religions of India in this short space of time.  Of course it can't be comprehensive, but it is representative.  It's a great way to communicate another world to the public.  We see snapshots of India which bring out what is brilliant and fascinating about the cultures of the sub-continent. Secondly it's filmed in a way that brings India to life. His narrative of these moments contextualizes and fascinates. The cinematography and score bring India are far above your standard "talking head" documentary.

reviewText: The movie truly gives you a feel for India, the culture and the country.  Very well done and interesting.  Two thumbs up.

reviewText: I visited India many many times over a 35 year period in my career in International business.I did not know all the intricate history that is released in these films.It is just brilliant work and the story teller is just compulsive viewing. Love the whole series..I am so disappointed this history was not part of my knowledge base at the time.for people interested read the book Freedom at midnight.It will give you abetter understanding of the hidden currents beneath the surface in the near east.
